Award.AbstractNarration:
Geometric measure theory is a field of mathematics that developed starting in the 1920s and 1930s, growing out of a practical need to describe nonsmooth phenomena such as the formation of corners in soap bubble clusters. The term "measure" refers to an abstract generalization of length, area, or volume, which assigns a size value to every mathematical set. Traditional outlets for geometric measure theory, such as the calculus of variations and geometric analysis, have expanded in recent decades to include partial differential equations and harmonic analysis. The widespread utility and current use of geometric measure theory in different areas of analysis justifies its continued development. The proposed investigation on the geometry of sets and measures seeks to develop new techniques that will expand the toolbox that geometric measure theory provides for researchers in adjacent areas in analysis and geometry.

This project focuses on two groups of questions about the geometry of sets and measures in Euclidean space. The first group of questions concerns rectifiable measures, one of the core objects of study in geometric measure theory. Specifically, these questions are aimed at increased understanding of rectifiable measures in the absence of a standing regularity assumption that has been assumed in the past. The main approach entails adapting quantitative techniques developed in the 1990s by Jones and David-Semmes to study the qualitative rectifiability of measures. The second group of questions are designed to examine the geometry of Reifenberg-type sets, which are sets that can be approximated at all locations and scales by one or more kinds of model sets. Instances where Reifenberg-type sets occur include geometric minimization problems and free boundary problems for elliptic partial differential equations. A general goal of this inquiry is to determine in what situations and to what extent good properties of solutions to problems in ideal models (smooth settings) persist under controlled perturbation (weak regularity).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In contemporary mathematics, measures are a ubiquitous tool, which allow us to assign a notion of size to mathematical sets,  encapsulating the familiar concepts of length, area, or volume. Despite their prevalence in many subfields of mathematics, the structure of general measures is still not very well understood and merit in depth investigation.

This project focused on two groups of questions about the geometry of sets and measures in Euclidean space. The first group of questions concerns rectifiable measures, one of the core objects in geometric measure theory. Specifically, these questions aimed at increasing our understanding of rectifiable measures in the absence of standing regularity assumptions that have been assumed in the past. The main approach entailed adapting quantitative techiniques developed in the 1990s by P. Jones, G. David and S. Semmes, to study the qualitative rectifiability of measures. The second group of questions are designed to examine the geometry of Reifenberg-type sets, which are sets that can be approximated at all locations and scales by one or more kinds of model sets. Instances where Reifenberg-type sets occur include geometric minimization problems and free boundary problems for elliptic partial differential equations. A goal of this inquiry is to determine in what situations and to what extent do good properties of solutions to problems in ideal models (smooth settings) persist under controlled perturabtion (weak regularity).

In joint work with R. Schul, the PI obtained a major breathrough on the first group of problems, by finding the first characterization of 1-rectifiable Radon measures in Euclidean space, i.e. locally finite measures in Euclidean space that are carried by curves of finite length. This work completes a long line of investigation started in the 1920s by A.S. Besicovitch in the early days of geometric measure theory that characterized 1-rectifiable Hausdorff measures restricted to sets of positive and finite length. The Badger-Schul characterization of 1-recitifable measures motivated followup work on "fractional rectifiability" by the PI, L. Naples, and V. Vellis, which established an Analyst's Traveling Salesman type criterion that ensures a set of points is contained in the image of a H?lder continuous curve.

On the second group of problems, the PI, M. Engelstein, and T. Toro completed two papers on non-variational two-phase free boundary problems for harmonic measure under weak and intermediate regularity regimes. In particular, we established uniform Lojasewicz type inequalities for harmonic polynomials and used them to prove a general structure theorem for Reifenberg-type sets that are well approximated by zero sets of harmonic polynomials. From this we obtained sharp estimates on the dimension of the singular set in the free boundary problem under weak regularity (subcontinuous, VMO data). In followup work, we proved an epiperimetric inequality for harmonic polynomial and used it to establish uniqueness of the blowups along the singular set and rectifiability of the singular set under intermediate regularity (H?lder continuous data). In related work, M. Akman, the PI, J.M. Martell, and S. Hofmann, characterized rectifiability of the boundary of a uniform domain in terms of absolute continuity of surface measure with respect to harmonic measure, or more generally, with respect to a class of elliptic measures associated to divergence form operators with Lipschitz coefficients.

The research activities carried out during the three and a half years of this award resulted in 4 publications, 1 manuscript awaiting publication, and 2 additional manuscripts under review. High-quality mathematics journals where this work appeared included the Transactions of the American Mathematical Society and The Journal of Geometric Analysis. The research results obtained were broadly disseminated in numerous conferences and research seminars at university across the United States, including in a plenary talk at the Eigth Ohio River Analysis Meeting in Lexington, Kentucky in March 2018. Broader impact of this work includes participation of a graduate student and two early-career researchers (postdocs) in the research projects.
